Tuition Reforms
The spiraling costs of private university education is
causing major dilemmas for both students and
administrators. With Hopkins' tuition at $2,700 next
September (and Dr. Gordon has already predicted
future hikes) it is becoming increasingly more difficult
to pretend that private schooling is open to every
qualified student regardless of his ability to pay.
Reports have circulated from such sources as
Director of Financial Aid Robert Kaufman that
freshmen scholarships may be sliced 50 per cent next
year. Coupled with the growing strength of public
universities and colleges, private education will soon be
hard-pressed to compete with state institutions and still
stay financially alive.
In the face of this Yale University is considering a
bold plan. It would allow students to take up to 35 years
to pay their tuition. Specifically, students would pay 0.4
per cent of their future income for every $1,000 in tuition
deferred, beginning when they leave school and
continuing for a maximum of 35 years.
A Yale official said, "The purpose of the plan is to
enable the university to charge somewhat higher tuition
without creating such a burden on a student from a
family with a low or middle income that he would not be
able to come. This plan enables everyone to pay a higher
charge even though the family can't really afford it."
For years Hopkins has had a policy of admitting
students without regard to financial need. Now on the
road to admitting only those who can pay and thus
jeopardizing a diversified student body, the University
must find a way to turn around. Yale's plan, we believe,
may provide the means.
Under the Yale proposal, the student would be
grouped with all those who began making payments in
the same year. When a group had paid off its total debt,
all of its members would be freed of their obligation. A
student could get out of the plan at any time by paying
150 per cent of the amount deferred plus interest.
If the plan receives final approval, Yale would stand
to get a return of five per cent on a sizeable investment
estimated at $25-30 million for the first five years. The
advantages to the University, however, and particularly
to students, are multi-fold. First, it would insure
maintenance of a diversified student body. Second,
students paying their own way would have increased
incentives to press for educational improvements.
As an interim step to weather the current inflationary
cycle in a more equitable manner, we would urge the
University to implement a "guaranteed tuition policy."
Under such a policy, the University would forfeit its
right to arbitrarily raise tuition and guarantee that the
tuition a student pays his first year will be the same that
he pays his last. When this year's senior class entered
Hopkins, tuition was $2,000. Each member of that class
has coughed up $750 more than he originally anticipated.
The junior class picture is even bleaker. By the time
graduation rolls around, they will have paid a whopping
$1,450 more than the catalogue told them it would cost at
the time they applied.
Bearing in mind that many students and their families
are just as financially hard-pressed as the University,
we urge the Student Council, the Graduate Student
Organization, the faculty and the administration to get
behind the plan for guaranteed tuition.
To ease its own burdens the University could
undertake the difficult job of predicting economic costs
over a four-year span as best it can,setting a price tag in
line with these costs for each entering class, and then
sticking with it. Then, at least, students and parents
would know what they were getting into.

Tuition Reforms
The spiraling costs of private university education is
causing major dilemmas for both students and
administrators. With Hopkins' tuition at $2,700 next
September (and Dr. Gordon has already predicted
future hikes) it is becoming increasingly more difficult
to pretend that private schooling is open to every
qualified student regardless of his ability to pay.
Reports have circulated from such sources as
Director of Financial Aid Robert Kaufman that
freshmen scholarships may be sliced 50 per cent next
year. Coupled with the growing strength of public
universities and colleges, private education will soon be
hard-pressed to compete with state institutions and still
stay financially alive.
In the face of this Yale University is considering a
bold plan. It would allow students to take up to 35 years
to pay their tuition. Specifically, students would pay 0.4
per cent of their future income for every $1,000 in tuition
deferred, beginning when they leave school and
continuing for a maximum of 35 years.
A Yale official said, "The purpose of the plan is to
enable the university to charge somewhat higher tuition
without creating such a burden on a student from a
family with a low or middle income that he would not be
able to come. This plan enables everyone to pay a higher
charge even though the family can't really afford it."
For years Hopkins has had a policy of admitting
students without regard to financial need. Now on the
road to admitting only those who can pay and thus
jeopardizing a diversified student body, the University
must find a way to turn around. Yale's plan, we believe,
may provide the means.
Under the Yale proposal, the student would be
grouped with all those who began making payments in
the same year. When a group had paid off its total debt,
all of its members would be freed of their obligation. A
student could get out of the plan at any time by paying
150 per cent of the amount deferred plus interest.
If the plan receives final approval, Yale would stand
to get a return of five per cent on a sizeable investment
estimated at $25-30 million for the first five years. The
advantages to the University, however, and particularly
to students, are multi-fold. First, it would insure
maintenance of a diversified student body. Second,
students paying their own way would have increased
incentives to press for educational improvements.
As an interim step to weather the current inflationary
cycle in a more equitable manner, we would urge the
University to implement a "guaranteed tuition policy."
Under such a policy, the University would forfeit its
right to arbitrarily raise tuition and guarantee that the
tuition a student pays his first year will be the same that
he pays his last. When this year's senior class entered
Hopkins, tuition was $2,000. Each member of that class
has coughed up $750 more than he originally anticipated.
The junior class picture is even bleaker. By the time
graduation rolls around, they will have paid a whopping
$1,450 more than the catalogue told them it would cost at
the time they applied.
Bearing in mind that many students and their families
are just as financially hard-pressed as the University,
we urge the Student Council, the Graduate Student
Organization, the faculty and the administration to get
behind the plan for guaranteed tuition.
To ease its own burdens the University could
undertake the difficult job of predicting economic costs
over a four-year span as best it can,setting a price tag in
line with these costs for each entering class, and then
sticking with it. Then, at least, students and parents
would know what they were getting into.
